The question:
Do more people die on their birthdays than expected?
I live in Massachusetts, so I got data on the 68,453 people who died in 2020.
The first thing we can do is count the number of days a person dies before or after their birthday on a circular calendar.
We‚Äôll start with Gus (made up name), who was born on March 4th, and after 84 years, died on March 4th. That‚Äôs a 0 day difference.
Two more examples: Gretchen, who was born on May 11th and died on May 2nd‚Äìa -9 day difference. And Randall who was also born on May 11th, but died on August 7th‚Äìan 87 day difference.
You get the picture. We arrange their relative death dates from -182 to 182 (days before and after birthday, respectively).

We do this for each person and count the number of times each difference occurs. If we expect death dates to be random relative to birthdays, this should look pretty flat. Instead, we can see some variation. Interesting‚Ä¶
But what we care about most is how many observations are on the zero day difference. Is it bigger? Enhance!
There are 17% excess birthday deaths compared to the average day difference.
We did it, we found the birthday effect!
But‚Ä¶
Look at this. Did you notice that just four days before birthdays it is even higher? Does that mean there is an ‚ÄúFour-days-before-a birthday effect‚Äù, too?

Maybe. But we‚Äôre likely facing a sample size issue here. Imagine trying to figure out if a coin is rigged towards landing on heads by flipping it just 10 times. You might get six heads and four tails, but that doesn‚Äôt prove much. You need more tests.The same thing is happening with our data.

We‚Äôre trying to detect if one specific value out of 365 is special. 68,453 observations might seem like a lot, but when you spread that over 365 days, we only expect about 188 deaths on any given day. But we expect some natural variation due to random chance since this is real life.

Statistics tells us the standard deviation would be about 14. In practice, this means we‚Äôd expect many (68%) of our observations to fall between 174-202 deaths (one standard deviation), and most (95%) to fall between 160-216 deaths (two standard deviations) ‚Äì even if there‚Äôs no birthday effect at all.
This natural variation in the data makes it hard to spot subtle patterns. We need a large enough sample to see if that birthday spike is truly meaningful or just random noise.
So I got data of every person who died in Massachusetts from 1990-2024. When we look at more years, we can see the noise factor play out. Some years, like 1999, will show a strong birthday effect.
While other years, like 2002, might show nothing at all.

But if we combine all 35 years I have (1990-2024), with nearly 2 million observations‚Äì5,358 per date‚Äìrandom fluctuations start to cancel out. This improves our ability to be more confident in our findings.
Now we see 6.9% excess birthday deaths. This is more promising.
But‚Ä¶
How confident can we be that our results are statistically significant, and how do we measure this?
Z-Tests and p-values baby!
To test significance, we start with the null hypothesis:
‚ÄúThere is no birthday effect. Deaths occur randomly throughout the year regardless of birthdays.‚Äù
Then we ask ourselves, how likely would we see this birthday spike by pure chance alone if our null hypothesis were true?
We calculate a z-score by taking the difference between observed and expected birthday deaths, then dividing by the standard deviation:
z = (observed - expected) / standard deviation
With 1,955,588 observations, we get a z-score of 5, which is extreme in the statistics world.

Converting this to a p-value tells us the probability of seeing this pattern if the null hypothesis were true.
Our p-value is ~0.000001, meaning there‚Äôs less than a 0.0001% chance we‚Äôd see this birthday effect if deaths were truly random.

So what have we learned?
The birthday effect shows that mortality isn‚Äôt just about biology and random chance; it‚Äôs influenced by social constructs and personal significance.
In a broader sense, this research reminds us that data can reveal hidden patterns in human experience that we might otherwise miss.
